column1: #FORMAT=WebAnno TSV 3.2
#T_SP=webanno.custom.Diy_coref|
#T_RL=webanno.custom.Diy_coref_re|BT_webanno.custom.Diy_coref
#Text=[0012] Another temperature management method for downhole electronics proposes a vapor compression temperature management system using water or other suitable liquid; e.g., FREON.RTM..
#Text=In this method, liquid in one tank is thermally coupled with the electronics chassis of the downhole tool.
#Text=The liquid absorbs heat via the heat exchanger from the downhole environment and the electronics, where the electronics are isolated from the liquid, and begins to vaporize.
#Text=For example, water would begin to vaporize at 100.degree.
#Text=C. so long as the pressure of the tank is maintained at 1.01.times.10.sup.5 Pa (14.7 psi).
#Text=To maintain the pressure, the steam is removed from the tank and compressed and stored in a second tank, which is at or near the temperature of the downhole environment.
#Text=However, sufficient steam must be removed from the first tank with a compressor to maintain the pressure at 1.01.times.10.sup.5 Pa.
#Text=Otherwise, the boiling point of the liquid will rise and thus raise the temperature of the electronics chassis in the first tank.
#Text=[0013] In practice, vaporization temperature management has significant problems.

#Text=First, a compressor must be supplied that is able to compress the vapor to a pressure greater than the saturation pressure of the vapor at the temperature of the downhole environment; e.g., 1.55.times.10.sup.6 Pa (225 psi) at 200.degree.
#Text=C. for water.
#Text=Second, the method does not isolate the thermal components but instead attempts to cool the entire electronics region.
#Text=While the average temperature of the region may remain at 100.degree.
#Text=C., the temperature of the discrete electronic components may be higher because they may internally generate heat.

#Text=Additionally, due to the typically low efficiency of most temperature management systems and the typically relatively high amount of heat to be extracted, substantial power may be required by the system.
#Text=This power is typically provided from downhole power generation devices such as turbine alternators.
#Text=However, the downhole power generation devices are typically powered by drilling fluid being pumped through the inside of the drill string during drilling.
#Text=At times during the drilling process, the pumping may be stopped to perform various tasks such as adding pipe to or removing pipe from the drill string.
#Text=When the pumping is stopped, the downhole power generation devices are unable to supply power to the heat exhausting temperature management system.

#Text=Thus, although temperature management is still required, those heat exhausting temperature management systems that require a source of power are unable to cool the thermal components when pumping is stopped because of the loss of power.
#Text=Even if batteries are provided downhole, they are limited in the duration for which they can provide power to the heat exhausting temperature management system.
#Text=[0014] Another temperature management method proposes a sorbent temperature management system.
#Text=This method again uses the evaporation of a liquid that is thermally connected via heat exchanger with the thermal components to manage the temperature of the components.

#Text=Instead of using a compressor to remove the vapor, this method uses desiccants in a second tank to absorb the vapor as it evaporates in a first tank, thus providing heat storage while requiring no input power.
#Text=However, the desiccants must absorb sufficient vapor in order to maintain a constant pressure in the first tank.
#Text=Otherwise, the boiling point of the liquid will rise as the pressure in the lower tank rises.
#Text=[0015] However, prior sorbent temperature management systems manage the temperature of the entire electronics region, not the discrete thermal components.
#Text=Thus, because of internal heat generation, the thermal components may remain at a higher temperature than the average temperature of the entire thermal component region.
#Text=Second, the desiccants must absorb sufficient vapor in order to maintain a constant pressure in the first tank.
#Text=Otherwise, the liquid will evaporate at a higher temperature and thus the temperature in the first tank will increase.
#Text=Further, the amount of water in the first tank limits the system.
#Text=Once all the water evaporates, the system no longer functions.

#Text=[0016] Another heat exhausting temperature management method involves a downhole thermoelectric refrigeration system comprising a cold heat exchanger and a hot heat exchanger thermally coupled by semiconductor materials.
#Text=With the thermoelectric refrigeration system, the cold heat exchanger of the temperature management system is thermally coupled with the thermal components.
